sen.j: 地子（じし/ちし）とは、日本の古代・中世から近世にかけて、領主が田地・畠地・山林・塩田・屋敷地などへ賦課した地代を指す。
sen.e: Jishi, also called chishi, (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) referred to the land rent which feudal lords imposed on rice fields, fields (for fruits, vegetables, etc.), mountains and forest, salt fields, or residential areas from ancient and medieval period to the early-modern times.

Jishi, also called chishi, (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) referred to the land rent which feudal lords imposed on rice fields, fields (for fruits, vegetables, etc.), mountains and forest, salt fields, or residential areas from ancient and medieval periods to the early-modern times.

Jishi, also called chishi, (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) referred to the land rent which feudal lords imposed on rice fields, fields (for fruits, vegetables, etc.), mountains and forest, salt fields, or residential areas from ancient and medieval periods to the early-modern times.

sen.j: 賦課した地目に応じて田地子・畠地子・塩浜地子・林地子・屋地子などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: It was called as denjishi (land rent for rice fields), hatajishi (land rent for fields for fruits, vegetables, etc), shiohamajishi (land rent for salt fields), hayashijishi (land rent for mountains and forest), or yajishi (land rent for residential areas) according to the classification of land imposed.
sen.cmt: 林地子 - 読み不明 hayashijishi としました。
sen.e: It was called denjishi (land rent for rice fields), hatajishi (land rent for fields for fruits, vegetables, etc), shiohamajishi (land rent for salt fields), hayashijishi (land rent for mountains and forest), or yajishi (land rent for residential areas) according to the classification of land imposed.

It was called denjishi (land rent for rice fields), hatajishi (land rent for fields for fruits, vegetables, etc), shiohamajishi (land rent for salt fields), hayashijishi (land rent for mountains and forest), or yajishi (land rent for residential areas) according to the classification of land imposed.

sen.j: 元々、地子は生産物地代の性格を持ち、その土地の生産物が地子として納入されていたが、中世後期ごろから貨幣経済が進展していくと、貨幣による地子の納入が増加していった。
sen.e: Originally, jishi had the characteristics of the tax payment in the form of products and the local products were brought in as jishi but jishi payment in money increased as the money economy gradually advanced from the late of the mid-period.

Originally, jishi had the characteristics of a tax payment in the form of products and the local products were brought in as jishi but jishi payment in money increased as the money economy gradually advanced from the late mid-period.

Originally, jishi had the characteristics of a tax payment in the form of products and the local products were brought in as jishi but jishi payment in money increased as the money economy gradually advanced from the late mid-period.

sen.j: そのため、米（稲）で納入する地子を地子米（地子稲）といい、銭で納入する地子を地子銭といって区別した。
sen.e: Therefore, jishi was distinguished into two forms: the one paid in rice (rice-plant) was called Jishimai or jishito (rice-plant paid as jishi) and the one paid in money was called jishisen (land taxes paid by tenant farmers).

Therefore, jishi was distinguished into two forms: the one paid in rice (rice-plant) was called Jishimai or jishito (rice-plant paid as jishi) and the one paid in money was called jishisen (land taxes paid by tenant farmers).

Therefore, jishi was distinguished into two forms: the one paid in rice (rice-plant) was called Jishimai or jishito (rice-plant paid as jishi) and the one paid in money was called jishisen (land taxes paid by tenant farmers).

sen.j: 8世紀初頭に成立した律令制のもとでは、公田のうち口分田を班給した後に余った乗田を国衙が百姓らに貸し付けて、収穫物の2割を納入させる賃租の規定があった（「田令公田条）。
sen.e: Under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) established at the beginning of the 8th century, there was a provision of chinso (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) that, after hankyu (allotment) of kubunden (the field given to each farmer in the Ritsuryo system), kokuga (provincial government offices) lent peasants joden (rest of the field after kubunden was given) from the remaining koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) and charged 20 percent of their harvest as jishi (according to "Denryo-koden-jo).
sen.cmt: 田令公田条 -読み、定訳不明 Denryo-koden-jo としています。
sen.e: Under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) established at the beginning of the 8th century, there was a provision of chinso (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) that, after hankyu (allotment) of kubunden (the field given to each farmer in the Ritsuryo system), kokuga (provincial government offices) lent peasants joden (rest of the field after kubunden was given) from the remaining koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) and charged 20 percent of their harvest as jishi (according to "Denryo-koden-jo).

Under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) established at the beginning of the 8th century, there was a provision of chinso (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) that, after hankyu (allotment) of kubunden (the field given to each farmer in the Ritsuryo system), kokuga (provincial government offices) lent peasants joden (rest of the field after kubunden was given) from the remaining koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) and charged 20 percent of their harvest as jishi (according to "Denryo-koden-jo).

sen.j: このとき、納入させた2割の収穫物を地子または地子稲（じしとう）と呼んだ。
sen.e: This 20 percent of the harvest charged was called jishi or jishito.
This 20 percent of the harvest charged was called jishi or jishito.
This 20 percent of the harvest charged was called jishi or jishito.

sen.j: 地子稲収入は畿内・伊賀国では正税の補充に、大宰府管内諸国では対馬国・多禰国（後に廃止）の公廨の補充に、陸奥国・出羽国では兵士の兵糧や蝦夷への狄禄の補充に充てられ、他の令制国では中央に近い諸国や沿岸諸国では舂米の形で、それ以外の国々では地子交易を行って軽貨の形で太政官厨家に納入されることが定められていた。
sen.e: Jishito revenue was used for replenishment of shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices' warehouse) in Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and Iga Province, and for maintaining public offices for Tsushima Province and Tane Province (abolished later) in provinces within Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), and for replenishment of army provisions for soldiers and of stipend to Ezo (northerners) in Mutsu Province and Dewa Province, and in other provinces under ryoseikoku (province), jishito was paid to Daijokan (Grand Council of State) in the form of shomai (rice made by pounding it in a mortar) in provinces near central government or sea and in the form of keika (fabrics such as silk or cotton or other local specialties) after doing jishi trade in provinces other than those.
sen.cmt: 狄禄 - 読み、定訳不明軽貨 - 定訳不明 silk or cotton fabrics or other local specialties としました。
sen.e: Jishito revenue was used for replenishment of shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices' warehouse) in the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and Iga Province, and for maintaining public offices for Tsushima Province and Tane Province (abolished later) in provinces within Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), and for replenishment of army provisions for soldiers and for stipends to Ezo (northerners) in Mutsu Province and Dewa Province, and in other provinces under ryoseikoku (province), jishito was paid to Daijokan (Grand Council of State) in the form of shomai (rice made by pounding it in a mortar) in provinces near the central government or sea and in the form of keika (fabrics such as silk or cotton or other local specialties) after doing jishi trade in provinces other than those.

Jishito revenue was used for replenishment of shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices' warehouse) in the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) and Iga Province, and for maintaining public offices for Tsushima Province and Tane Province (abolished later) in provinces within Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), and for replenishment of army provisions for soldiers and for stipends to Ezo (northerners) in Mutsu Province and Dewa Province, and in other provinces under ryoseikoku (province), jishito was paid to Daijokan (Grand Council of State) in the form of shomai (rice made by pounding it in a mortar) in provinces near the central government or sea and in the form of keika (fabrics such as silk or cotton or other local specialties) after doing jishi trade in provinces other than those.

sen.j: なお賃租は、国衙だけでなく、初期荘園を経営する大寺社なども行っていた。
sen.e: Chinso was also imposed by not only kokuga but also main temples and shrines that ran early shoens (manors in medieval Japan).
Chinso was also imposed by not only kokuga but also main temples and shrines that ran early shoens (manors in medieval Japan).
Chinso was also imposed by not only kokuga but also main temples and shrines that ran early shoens (manors in medieval Japan).

sen.j: 初期荘園は賃租に伴う地子収入によって経営されていた。
sen.e: The early shoens were run on the income from land taxes accompanied with this chinso.
The early shoens were run on the income from land taxes accompanied with this chinso.
The early shoens were run on the income from land taxes accompanied with this chinso.

sen.j: 9世紀から10世紀ごろにかけて、富豪百姓らによる私領（私営田）の形成が進んでいった。
sen.e: Forming of private land (shieiden (lands directly governed by powerful families)) had been accelerated by wealthy farmers from the 9th century to the 10th century.
Forming of private land (shieiden (lands directly governed by powerful families)) had been accelerated by wealthy farmers from the 9th century to the 10th century.
Forming of private land (shieiden (lands directly governed by powerful families)) had been accelerated by wealthy farmers from the 9th century to the 10th century.

sen.j: 私領も国家租税である官物の賦課対象であったが、領主は、私領から私的な得分を収取することについて国衙の承認を受けており、地子の語はこの私的得分を指すようになった。
sen.e: Although private lands were also objects for imposition of kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), the national land tax, feudal lords obtained the recognition of kokuga to the right to collect profit personally and the term of jishi referred to this personal profit.

Although private lands were also objects for imposition of kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), the national land tax, feudal lords obtained the recognition of kokuga to the right to collect profit personally and the term of jishi referred to this personal profit.

Although private lands were also objects for imposition of kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), the national land tax, feudal lords obtained the recognition of kokuga to the right to collect profit personally and the term of jishi referred to this personal profit.

sen.j: さらに11世紀から12世紀にかけて荘園または荘園公領制が成立すると、それまで国家租税とされていた官物の収取権が、荘園領主へ移譲されていき、官物は年貢へと変質した。
sen.e: Furthermore, when the shoen or the shoen koryo-sei (the system of public lands and private estates) was established from the 11th century to the 12th century, the right to collect kanmotsu which had been considered as national land tax was transferred to lords of manor and the kanmotsu changed its nature to nengu (land tax).

Furthermore, when the shoen or the shoen koryo-sei (the system of public lands and private estates) was established from the 11th century to the 12th century, the right to collect kanmotsu which had been considered as national land tax was transferred to lords of manors and the kanmotsu changed its nature to nengu (land tax).

Furthermore, when the shoen or the shoen koryo-sei (the system of public lands and private estates) was established from the 11th century to the 12th century, the right to collect kanmotsu which had been considered as national land tax was transferred to lords of manors and the kanmotsu changed its nature to nengu (land tax).

sen.j: 年貢は、官物、ひいては田租に由来しており、荘園租税体系の中心に位置する税目であり、現地の下級荘園領主（開発領主や荘官など）が上級領主へ納入すべき税目であった。
sen.e: The nengu came from kanmotsu, eventually denso (rice field tax), and became central items of taxation in the land tax system for shoens and the item of taxation that were paid to high grade lords of the manor by local low grade lords of the manor (kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) or shokan (an officer governing shoen (manor))).

The nengu came from kanmotsu, eventually denso (rice field tax), and became central items of taxation in the land tax system for shoens and the item of taxation that were paid to high grade lords of the manor by local low grade lords of the manor (kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) or shokan (an officer governing shoen (manor))).

The nengu came from kanmotsu, eventually denso (rice field tax), and became central items of taxation in the land tax system for shoens and the item of taxation that were paid to high grade lords of the manor by local low grade lords of the manor (kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land) or shokan (an officer governing shoen (manor))).

sen.j: かりに年貢しか徴収しないとすると、現地の下級領主の得分は何も存在しないことになる。
sen.e: If only nengu was collected, there was nothing left that local low grade lords could have as their profit.
If only nengu was collected, there was nothing left that local low grade lords could have as their profit.
If only nengu was collected, there was nothing left that local low grade lords could have as their profit.

sen.j: そのため、下級領主たちは自らの得分とすべく、様々な名目で地代を荘民から収取するようになった。
sen.e: Therefore, to get their shares, the low grade lords collected the land rent under the various pretexts from shomin (people of the manor).
Therefore, to get their shares, the low grade lords collected the land rent under various pretexts from shomin (people of the manor).
Therefore, to get their shares, the low grade lords collected the land rent under various pretexts from shomin (people of the manor).

sen.j: これが中世における地子である。
sen.e: This was the jishi in the medieval period.
This was jishi in the medieval period.
This was jishi in the medieval period.

sen.j: 地子は加地子と呼ばれることもあった。
sen.e: This jishi was also called kajishi (land rent).
This jishi was also called kajishi (land rent).
This jishi was also called kajishi (land rent).

sen.j: 中には、本年貢の数倍に及ぶ地子を収取する領主が存在したことも、記録に残っている。
sen.e: According to a record, some land lords collected jishi as much as several times of real nengu.
According to a record, some land lords collected jishi amounting to as much as several times the real nengu.
According to a record, some land lords collected jishi amounting to as much as several times the real nengu.

sen.j: 中世の中期（鎌倉時代中期・後期）ごろから、商品流通の活発化とそれに伴う貨幣経済の進展が次第に顕著となっていくと、地子を貨幣で納入する事例が増えていった。
sen.e: From around the middle of the medieval period (the mid or the late Kamakura period), as the commercial distribution became more active and the money economy accompanied with it gradually became pronounced, more and more jishi was paid in money.

From around the middle of the medieval period (the mid or late Kamakura period), as commercial distribution became more active and the money economy accompanied with it gradually became pronounced, more and more jishi was paid in money.

From around the middle of the medieval period (the mid or late Kamakura period), as commercial distribution became more active and the money economy accompanied with it gradually became pronounced, more and more jishi was paid in money.

sen.j: これを地子銭という。
sen.e: It was called jishisen.
It was called jishisen.
It was called jishisen.

sen.j: 地子銭の納入は決して多くはなく、一部の都市（京）などにとどまっていたが、中世末期の戦国時代 (日本)ごろになると、農村部でも銭貨による地子納入の事例が見られるようになった。
sen.e: The payment of jishisen was not much in any sense and it was limited to some big cities (imperial capital) but cases of jishi payment in coins became common even in rural areas in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in the end of mediaeval period (Japan).

The payment of jishisen was not much in any sense and it was limited to some big cities (imperial capital) but cases of jishi payment in coins became common even in rural areas in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in the end of the medieval period (Japan).

The payment of jishisen was not much in any sense and it was limited to some big cities (imperial capital) but cases of jishi payment in coins became common even in rural areas in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in the end of the medieval period (Japan).

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の太閤検地によって、中間得分の収取が否定された。
sen.e: Due to the taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, collection of interim dividends was disapproved.
Due to the taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, collection of interim dividends was disapproved.
Due to the taiko kenchi (the cadastral surveys) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, collection of interim dividends was disapproved.

sen.j: これは、中世的な地子が廃止されたことを意味する。
sen.e: This means that jishi in the medieval periods was abolished.
This means that jishi in the medieval periods was abolished.
This means that jishi in the medieval periods was abolished.

sen.j: 以後、近世には田地へ賦課される地子は見られなくなった。
sen.e: After that, the jishi that was imposed on rice fields was not seen.
After that, jishi that was imposed on rice fields was not seen.
After that, jishi that was imposed on rice fields was not seen.

sen.j: ただし、都市域において屋敷地に賦課される地代が地子と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: On the other hand, the land rent which was imposed on the residential areas in urban regions became to be called jishi.
On the other hand, the land rent which was imposed on the residential areas in urban regions came to be called jishi.
On the other hand, the land rent which was imposed on the residential areas in urban regions came to be called jishi.

sen.j: 都市では貨幣経済が定着していたため、地子は銭貨で納入されるのが一般的であり、地子銭と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In urban areas where the money economy was already in place, jishi was usually paid in coined money and was called jishisen.
In urban areas where the money economy was already in place, jishi was usually paid in coined money and was called jishisen.
In urban areas where the money economy was already in place, jishi was usually paid in coined money and was called jishisen.

sen.j: 明治になり、近代税制が確立すると地子は姿を消した。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, jishi disappeared as the modern tax system was established.
In the Meiji period, jishi disappeared as the modern tax system was established.
In the Meiji period, jishi disappeared as the modern tax system was established.

sen.j: 明治以降でも、地主が小作から収取する地代は地子的性格を有していたが、これは小作料と称された。
sen.e: Even after the Meiji period, jishi that landlords collected from their tenant farmers maintained the characteristics of jishi but it was called farm rent.
Even after the Meiji period, jishi that landlords collected from their tenant farmers maintained the characteristics of jishi but it was called farm rent.
Even after the Meiji period, jishi that landlords collected from their tenant farmers maintained the characteristics of jishi but it was called farm rent.
